sourcesContent:
import FuseHighlight from '@fuse/core/FuseHighlight'; import Typography from '@mui/material/Typography'; /* eslint import/no-webpack-loader-syntax: off */ /* eslint import/extensions: off */ function MultiLanguageDoc() { return ( <> Multi Language Fuse React uses{' '} react-i18next {' '} for to support multiple languages. Since not everybody need multi-language setup for their apps, we decided NOT to put translations everywhere. If you want to see the translations in action, visit the Mail app, and then change the language from the Toolbar. Mail app is the only app that has translations for demonstration purposes. You can look at its source code to see the usage. Usage In order to use the translations, create your translation file within the folder you want to use the translations. For example, for the Mail app, create i18n/en.js file inside the apps/mail folder. {require('!raw-loader!src/app/main/apps/mailbox/i18n/en.js')} And register the language file with i18next.addResourceBundle() at src/app/main/apps/mailbox/MailboxAppConfig.js {require('!raw-loader!src/app/main/apps/mailbox/MailboxAppConfig.js')} And use in a component with useTranslation hook as below: {` import {useTranslation} from 'react-i18next'; const {t} = useTranslation('mailApp'); return (
`} Default Language To change the default language of the Fuse React, you need to change lng{' '} setting in the file src/i18n.js You can change "eng" value to "ar" to test it out. {require('!raw-loader!src/i18n.js')} Changing Language You should use changeLanguage redux action to change language dynamically: {` import { changeLanguage } from 'app/store/i18nSlice'; . . dispatch(changeLanguage(lng.id)); `} Checkout example usage at app/theme-layouts/shared-components/LanguageSwitcher.js ); } export default MultiLanguageDoc;
